Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Towards a Better Understanding of Ambient Semi-volatile Organic Aerosol: Investigation of Thermodynamic Properties of Multi-component Organic Aerosols
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to obtain empirical parameterizations of thermodynamic properties of multi-component organic aerosol to be used in chemical transport models. The main hypothesis is that volatility of an organic compound in a mixture is a function of the carbon number and the polarity of this compound, as well as those of the mixture; and that volatility of the total mixture can be predicted using a simplified matrix containing binned data on the carbon number and polarity of each of the compounds in the mixture. Prediction of ambient semi-volatile organic aerosol remains highly problematic and air quality models often do not agree with observations. The lack of understanding of the partitioning of semi-volatile compounds between the gas and the complex aerosol matrix is one of the main reasons for this discrepancy.

In this study the equilibrium thermodynamic properties of multi-component aerosols will be investigated under controlled laboratory conditions as well as in the field. In the laboratory experiments model mixtures of organic compounds as well as modified ambient aerosols will be tested. The ambient aerosols will be modified in a controlled way by adding known amounts of different organic substances of known thermodynamic properties and variable molecular weight and polarity. The equilibrium gas/aerosol partitioning in a temperature range relevant to ambient conditions will be investigated using the Integrated Volume Method (IVM), developed in the principal investigator's (PI) laboratory. The results will be used to derive equilibrium vapor pressures and activity coefficients of test compounds as a function of their carbon number and polarity and to determine the minimum number of bins along these dimensions that will adequately represent ambient aerosol volatility.

This project will improve the understanding, predictions and control of the major fraction of ambient aerosol, which is relevant for public health and global climate change. The educational and outreach component will be directed at a wide audience in order to help educate the public about the current environmental problems related to air pollution and help attract students to environmental science and engineering. Special attention will be given to attracting and retaining under-represented groups, such as women and minorities. The project will include an educational outreach component with hands-on experience for middle school students; summer research projects will be offered to students from the North Carolina School of Science and Math, for graduate and undergraduate students at Duke University and North Carolina Central University (NCCU), an Historically Black University. The research results will be disseminated via conferences and peer-reviewed publications. To reach a wider audience the PI plans to utilize the power of social media tools, such as Facebook groups, to share the research results and engage the community directly.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The goal of the project was to study fundamental processes that control distribution of semi-volatile air pollutants between gas and particle phases in ambient aerosols, microscopic particles suspended in air. Partitioning of semi-volatile compounds is one of the largest uncertainties in predicting concentration of ambient particulate matter concentrations. The work focused on investigation of the role of basic chemically relevant parameters, such as the size and polarity of molecules, and their relative abundance in aerosol mixtures. Time scales of achieving gas/particle equilibrium were also investigated.

The key results of this project are:

  1. A novel experimental method has been developed to determine key parameters that control time required for achieving gas/particle equilibrium.
  2. Key parameters that control aerosol equilibration were determined (particle size, particle concentration, and the probability of molecule accommodation on particle surface). It was found that compound volatility affects the equilibration time only as a ratio to the particle concentration. Regions were delineated in which each parameter becomes a rate-limiting factor.
  3. It was found that equilibration of multi-component aerosols can be approximated by that of a single-component aerosol.
  4. Equilibration times vary from seconds for high aerosol concentrations to days or longer for dilute aerosols that have low surface accommodation efficiency or are composed of highly viscous or solid material. Surface accommodation and physical state of PM are key parameters that need to be studied further to verify the equilibrium assumption used in air quality models.
  5. Based on experiments with laboratory-generated aerosol mixtures, current parameterizations used in air quality models (single and two component approximations and volatility basis set approximations) reproduce experimental observations of gas/particle partitioning within 50%, on average. Larger deviations were observed, however, when aerosols were composed of compounds with strongly different polarities, probably due to separation of compounds into different solid or liquid phases. The assumption of complete mixing that is used in air quality models could, thus, be invalid in geographic regions where fresh non-polar emissions are mixed with aged aerosols that tend to be composed of polar compounds.   

BROADER IMPACTS

Ambient aerosols, a significant portion of which is composed of semi-volatile organic compounds, have substantial environmental effects, such as adverse health effects and impact on global climate. Organic fraction is one of the least understood aspects of ambient aerosol and its prediction by current chemical transport models is highly problematic. This project provides data necessary to improve these models and, thus, our ability to predict and control particulate air pollution. 

The results of this project have been distributed to a wider community via three peer-reviewed publications (two more are currently in preparation), ten presentations at national and international conferences, and six invited presentations.

The project resulted in training two graduate students and a female high school student. The high school student’s project was selected as a semi-finalist of Intel Science Talent Search competition.
